Darwinism? How does it deal with the bacterial flagellum, for example?
If we take Behe at his word when he declares that he finds “the idea of
common descent” to be “fairly convincing,” and that he has “no particular
reason  to  doubt  it,”*then  we  should  suppose  that  bacteria  with  flagella
emerged from ancestors who lacked flagella. In line with the simple addi-
tive story he uses to make a history of natural selection appear implausible,
he must suppose that the ancest
